resource.chars:
For when the face is pointed downwards, the eyes that 
look at us must be turned upwards from the position 
of the face to which they belong. And, if to eyes 
so drawn an upward cast of features be substituted 
for the former, the eyes seem immediately to look 
above us.
When the turn of a pair of eyes partakes of both 
inclinations, so as to be in a direction laterally 
upwards, the alteration produced by changing the 
position of the face affords the most striking 
exemplification of the force of this principle, as 
may be seen in Plate III & its companion.
But the effect thus producible is by no means 
limitted to the mere extent of deviation, as a total 
difference of character may be given to the same
